In chemistry, an 'imino acid' is any molecule that contains both imino (>C=NH)
and carboxyl (-C(=O)-OH) functional groups.

{{multiple image
| footer = The two functional groups that together define an imino acid align =
| left image1 = Imine General Structure B.png width1 = 83 caption1 =
| Imine image2 = Carboxylic-acid.svg width2 = 112 caption2 =
| Carboxylic acid
}}

Imino acids are related to amino acids, which contain both amino (-
NH 2) and carboxyl (-COOH) functional groups, differing in the bonding
to the nitrogen.

The amino acid oxidase enzymes are able to convert amino acids into imino acids.
Also the direct biosynthetic precursor to the amino acid proline is the imino
acid (S)-Î 1-pyrroline-5-carboxylate (P5C).
